column17: description

The Author is an artisan, like the Painter and the Bard. The important difference between them is their relation to the facts that they present. As a Moon card, the Author faces mysteries. So the Author is a character of investigation, enquiry, and at most partial answers.
Morning light shines through clear water. The Origin can appear as either a location or an event. As an event, it is morning light. As a location, it is a living spring.
Barren and without life, the Desert offers a certain grim clarity. Yet clarity might itself be a mirage.
Even if the Savage presents a pleasant face, the wild lurks in his heart.
The Painter is a figure of revelation. The Painter sees through posturing and portrays things as they need to be portrayed.
The Journey is in between. It is its own story, written between departure and arrival.
Struggle with forces that are half in shadow. It is not always obvious what those forces are until they have done their worst.
A quest leads to the peak. Especially if the Mountain appears in a spread with the Journey, to the peak may be more important than at the peak.
On the wall of the sailor's house: He is not at home at home. The Sailor is a traveller by nature, uneasy when not underway.
Something buried or lost is found. The Discovery may be the end of a quest or as surprising as a sudden storm.

Like words to the Author or money to the Merchant, war is craft to the Soldier. Although the conflict might not be a literal war, the Soldier lives for it. The soldier's craft is wrought in stillness and motion. Of all the personalities, the Soldier shows the least difference between its two faces.
The Forest is usually a literal card representing a forest or wooded place. In a crowded city, however, sometimes even a single tree can be a forest.

The Market can appear as either a location or an event. As a location, the Market is a place of trade. As an event, the Market is commerce. Unlike the Pact, it does not suggest a great confluence; an exchange, and the matter is resolved.
A higher calling hides a darker past. Redemption is never entirely complete for the Penitent.
The Lunatic sees things that no one else sees. Perhaps these are deeper truths, perhaps they are delusions. Watch the great tumult around her.
Two stories half-written find themselves writing one another. The Chance Meeting is a card of possibilities.
The Castle is a community. It is a place of civility or power, but only rarely of both.

It is home to grim things and a place of challenges. Things that fall below the surface may be found in the Cave, even if they were long thought lost or destroyed. To enter and return from it once should be enough.
Even a soft hand can wield a sharp knife. This is a time to be wary.
The Diplomat mediates between opposites: darkness and light, patience and action, the one and the many.
The Mill is a place of craft and production. The tuneless song of the miller is lost in the roar of the water and the ceaseless turning of the wheel.
When the two kings agree, the stones themselves agree. Even a Pact between just two parties has ramifications for the community and the broader world.
For the Merchant, wealth is its own end. The Merchant amasses riches, but worries all the while about losing them.

The Darkness can settle on familiar places and hides all manner of things. Although one may hide there or seek for what is lost there, it is best not to tarry there too long. Unlike the Cave, it is sometimes best to illuminate and dispel the Darkness rather than to flee from it.
The Bard speaks and people listen. Whereas the Painter can paint the world as it is, things become the way the Bard says they ought to be.

The Huntress finds her mark, like an arrow loosed from a bow. She is a seeker, even if she is unsure what she is seeking, and she is on a quest even in her idle moments. The Huntress stands in the natural world, like a tree in the forest. In some ways, she acts just like an animal; she moves without reflection, in accord with her nature.
The Sea is often literally some large body of water. As a symbol, it is the source of storms.

The End can appear as either a location or an event. As an event, the End is the conclusion of the cycle before the beginnings of the next moment are even buds on the branches. As a location, the End is a terminus at the border of known lands with nothing on the other side.
Death so sudden that there is no time to bury the dead. Although it can be mitigated by other cards in the spread, the Calamity is always a bad thing.
One might have quested for it, if one had known, but it comes unannounced. The Windfall on its own is always a positive card. If there is any cost or caveat, it must come from somewhere else.
Waits for danger to arise and responds, but he may be too late if the he is not perceptive or lucky enough.
The edge of things. A place of chance and uncertainty, harbouring threats and resources in equal measure.
Things come together. What was reaped may be sown. Patience is rewarded. Unlike the Windfall, the Harvest requires preparation and demands labour.
Averts danger. Unlike the reactive Watchman, the Light Keeper prepares for the worst in an attempt to create conditions under which danger is overcome even before it arises.

Beginners are advised to leave the Excuse out of the deck when telling fortunes. Although some practitioners include it and assign it a special role, there is disagreement about what that role ought to be. Some interpret it as an event. Others interpret it not as being about an excuse, but rather as the deck excusing itself: The matter is too unsettled to say anything helpful, or the question is posed in such an awkward way that saying anything would be misleading.
